title: Did Ilayaraja copy music from others for his songs? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is not exactly copying. Many times he experiments. I can give you few examples.. 1) Take "Ada veettukku" song from kizhakku vasal. Nobody expected that he would have used Mozart's 25th symphony(Titan theme music) to compose a Tamil folk song(therukoothu) until he revealed that in a concert in Italy. The beauty lies in the adaptation of purest form of western classical into raw folk music as the lyric goes "theru koothukkum pattukkum Thala jathi venum" which roughly means for folk music you need rhythm.There are so many songs he got inspired from the western classical masters and he never hesitates to mention that in every opportunity.    2) He did just the reverse of the above. Taking folk music and backing up with western classical elements. Take the example of "poove ilaya poove" from kozhi koovudhu. He main melody is a thalaattu (lullaby) sung around Madurai region. He would have backed with amazing orchestration with strings, guitar, flute etc. There are so many examples such as "Aayiram thamarai mottukale" in which he used kummi, "Manguyile poonguyile" song, "Annakili unna theduthe" and many more. It's not only the western songs he was inspired from as Kowsika Raju mentioned. He also gave us the hidden treasure of folk music without him we wouldn't have even heard those gems. There is a lot of difference between copying and inspiration. One cannot create music from vacuum. First one has to be a sincere listener to become a creator. There is no wrong in acknowledging great compositions by getting inspired by them and using that inspiration in their own music.

Ilaiyaraaja is the kind of musical brain that when he hears Bach's Bouree in E minor, he writes a counter Indian melody on top of it:     He is the kind of talent that when he hears Schubert's unfinished symphony he extends it and gives it a closure with his own composition of 'Ithayam Poguthe':  When he hears one of the shortest Pallavi  composed in Carnatic music - "tatva meruga tarama" by Thyagaraja Swamigal - he challenges himself to do the longest pallavi possible and comes up with "Tham thana nam thana":     So this is Ilaiyaraaja. A once a life time genius that comes along !  There is no denial of the fact that some of the original tracks  quoted in the first answer is directly used in an Ilaiyaraaja tune. But all such songs (and perhaps the remaining 700 odd songs claimed to be in that list) are no different than the above videos I have provided. (Of course there could be exceptions like the 'Kasme wade' song were a full length song is reused due to an external non-musical reason) .  These songs are unique windows that offers us an insight into how Ilaiyaraaja's mind works.   So the word 'Copy' that is used in your question is a rather demeaning word that tries to imply Ilaiyaraaja as a plagiarist, While in reality all of 2 bars of someone else's musical idea challenges him and he decides to do his own version of it. He picks such masterpieces as his starting point - sometimes "as is" as you call it - and makes it as his own master piece by adding 130 or 140 bars of original music on top of it. While you are quick to point out the similarity in 2 lines of a song, please also record the fact that each of such song goes on to have an original prelude, two original interludes and an original stanza that often has no resemblance to the source song. It is a clear demonstration of "What if I do the same thing.." by Ilaiyaraaja.

Short biography of Ilayaraja and his copied or inspirational songs list – Reality Views by sm – Saturday, June 26, 2010 Name – Ilaiyaraaja [Gnanadesikan] Birth Date - Born 2 June 1943 Place of Birth : Pannaipuram in Theni District of Tamil Nadu Parents : Daniel Ramaswamy Vs Chinnathayee Daughter : Bhavatharini Sons : Karthikeyan,Yuvan Shankar Wife : Jeeva(Own sister's Daughter) Profession – music composer, lyricist, music director, Poet His works are mainly in Tamil and Telugu. Ilaiyaraaja specialized in classical guitar and had done a course in it with the Trinity College of Music, London. At the age of 14, he joined a traveling musical troupe headed by his elder stepbrother, Pavalar Varadarajan Ilaiyaraaja worked as a session guitarist, keyboardist, and organist for film music composers and directors such as Salil Chowdhury Ilaiyaraaja was one of the early Indian film composers to use Western classical music harmonies and string arrangements in Indian film music. Laiyaraaja’s composition Rakkama Kaiya Thattu from the movie Thalapathi (1991) was amongst the songs listed in a BBC World Top Ten music poll. He has worked with international bands as well as given music score for the miss world 1996, Bangalore. He has received many awards I am just mentioning few awards.He has received NTR National Award for the year 2004. He has received Padma Bhushan award in the year 2010. Conferred the Cultural Doctorate in Philosophy of Music, in April, 1994, by the World University Round Table, Arizona, U.S.A. Bestowed with the honorary citizenship and presented with the key to the Teanech Township, by Mr. John Abraham, Mayor of Township of Teanech, New Jersey, U.S.A., in June, 1994.
